Time is polar. You either exist in +1 time, or you live in -1 time. For every +1 time there is an equal and opposite -1 time. "Absolute time" ie, time + anti=time = 0. As if time itself does not exist at all. But, we experience time because of its polar nature. In +1 time matter expands. In - 1 time, matter contracts. These effects cancel out so we do not experience either expansion or contraction. Matter close by the observer seems to be expanding. On earth that expansion is measured at 9.8 m/s^2. Matter far away from an observer seems to be contracting. We "observe" the far away contraction as matter getting smaller and smaller, or as our instruments are incorrectly telling us, it is accelerating away from us at ever greater accelerations depending on distance.

In reality, all matter is static. What you see is what you get. The earth is not expanding up against your feet and far away galaxies are not shrinking in relative size. There's an unhealthy focus on "the observer" in physics. As if somehow it were the fundamental difference between actual results. But it is more accurate to say that everything is made out of movement. And so an "observer" simply adds movement to another system made out of movement. Which results in a different result, or understanding of the situation.

The subtlety is that we can't actually conclude anything on the observation without further breaking down the movement. As far as I understand, a lot of physics revolves around different scales of conclusion. And a lot of the confusion arises when trying to use the same entities to conclude a meaningful result, in different scales of conclusion.

To avoid this, all we need to do is try to understand every particle, every group of particles as what they are suspiciously trying to tell us they are: movement itself. Or to make it truly accurate: the specific movement that we can best use to describe it locally.

I don’t know if it's an artifact of educational videos, or deeper problem with the discipline, but it looks like, from my perspective that physics is trying to conclude on all scales simultaneously, some master equation that somehow still means something to all systems.

I do not think this is wise. Probably better to explain all things *we know of*, to all other things *we know of*, instead of looking for some common universal point between "all things". In this case slapping on all things the very theoretical title of "observer".

I have often thought along similar lines to the end of this video and completely agree with the series of points and intuitive interpretations made, and with almost all of the presentation at the start. However, there is a problem with the description of the falling man 5:23. First, if he starts falling at the top, the colour he sees is the colour the photon ends up, which is red, say (the video said "blue"). And at the bottom he is moving fast in the opposite direction to the photon. The Doppler effect (referred to in the video) is dependent on direction - if he ran into the photon low down the tower it would be bluer for two reasons - his velocity and gravitational blueshift. So that's not the right reasoning - the colours at the top and the bottom don't agree. Of course it would be the relativistic Doppler effect if anything (because that's the relevant physics) but this is still a direction-dependent effect that is opposite to what we are looking for. As he falls, the relativistic Doppler effect would blueshift photons that are already more energetic because of being lower in the gravitational field (as observed by building dwellers), so this is not what we want! What works to make the photons look the same colour at all heights is the special relativistic time dilation, gamma. Let's check this.

The gravitational redshift is to first order a factor of (1 + gh/c^2), where h is the height below the top of the tower, our chosen reference (which happens to be where the falling man is stationary)
The velocity of the falling man is sqrt(2gh), so gamma is 1 / sqrt(1 - 2gh/c^2) at any distance below the top, which is to an excellent approximation (1 + gh/c^2).

Thus this factor applied to the frequencies observed by observers in the building makes the photons the same shade of red as they were at the top of the tower. QED ;)

I don't think you're right actually. In fact photons DO get stretched, the redshifting is NOT due to the doppler effect! Doppler shifts are caused by an object’s motion through space, whereas a cosmological redshift is caused by the expansion of space. In Hubble’s law, the original interpretation of redshifts was that they were due to Doppler shifts by receding galaxies; this works because for small redshifts, the Doppler shift can account for the recession of galaxies in expanding space. However, the full properties of expanding space, described by Einstein’s general theory of relativity, must be taken into account for larger redshifts. In fact, at redshifts (z) greater than about 1.5, galaxies are observed with recessional velocities greater than the speed of light! While this would violate the laws of physics in a static universe, recessional speeds can exceed the speed of light in an expanding universe.

Let’s think for just a moment, what if the redshift we are seeing from far distant galaxies is actually not caused by the strange unexplainable cosmological expansion but from a much simpler, readily explainable mechanism, perpendicular gravitational influence.  Before you dismiss this idea, please let me complete the explanation.  Light travels as a transverse wave similar to ocean waves.  For a moment let’s compare a tsunami event to redshift.  As a long low amplitude wave moves through the deep ocean it travels fast and as it reaches shallow shores the wave slows, shortens and gains amplitude because the earth under the water is pushing the wave upward toward the wave if you will.  Now to reach earth, light from a far galaxy must travel for billions of years through space passing by an untold number of gravitational sources that produce a perpendicular force on the light as it passes through the gravitational fields.  Since the light is not polarized and the gravity sources would come from all sides of the light, the gravity would produce the opposite effect that land’s influence on a tsunami waves would produce.  This perpendicular gravitation influence on the light wave would cause the light to red shift.  No mysterious cosmological expansion required.

Also, by the way, an observer in an accelerating vehicle (elevator or rocket or whatever) and an observer in 1g gravity are in completely different environments. The observer in the rocket
has the same force throughout the vehicle. The observer in 1g gravity is in a gravity field. The gravity at head height is different than the gravity at foot level.

COSMOLOGICAL REDSHIFT ALTERNATIVE: Spontaneous reddening of starlight

The following rather expansive speculation concerns how the light from an astronomical object can spontaneously shift to lower frequencies during its travel through empty space.

Although the idea stems for me from my view of the photon, it may not be crucially dependent on that view.

LIGHT

Let us discuss the optical region of the spectrum, and for clarity, let us discuss light of a “single” frequency ν. If a star has a spectral luminosity L_ν, then the intensity of this light at a distrance R from the star is I_ν:

I_ν = L_ν /4π R**2 (1)

The spectral energy density u_ν at this location due to the star is

u_ν = I_ν /c, (2)

c being the velocity of light.

PHOTON

The photon in my view has a size (just physical size). The photon is a structure made of magnetic field in empty space, and this structure at a given frequency is defined by an inverse length parameter α. I will now say that the length is typically the wavelength λ (~ 1/α ~ c/ν). So – not surprisingly – the photon occupies a volume of the order V ~ λ**3. By superposition, the same volume of course can simultaneously be occupied by an unlimited number of photons in a continuum of frequencies.

LIGHT-PHOTON LINKAGE

I am also interested in how the photons constitute light (the way – as a very simplistic example – vehicles constitute a convoy). I believe there is some type of a linkage in the sense of classical physics, but I have no specific ideas in this regard thus far. For now just accept this proposition which should not be found too objectionable: Whatever the photon-makeup of light is, it must always hold for ligh to remain light. If adjacent vehicles in a convoy move a mile apart, then it is no longer a convoy.



When the distance R equals R_ν, a distance so large that

u_ν Δν V ~ h ν, (3)

i.e, the stellar energy available in the volume occupied by the photon is the same as the photon energy hν, a critical juncture is reached. At greater distances there is not enough energy available for photons to exist in a connected continuum. The light-photon linkage fails when the intensity falls below a threshold.

PHOTON BANDWIDTH Δν

The bandwidth Δν which we are forced to introduce above is in fact exactly what is called for from any view of the photon as a free-standing magnetic structure. Consider (in principle) translating such an isolated structure at the velocity c past a light detector connected to a suitably fast oscilloscope. Then an electromagnetic pulse will be recorded – a pulse which begins at zero amplitude and ends in zero amplitude. When this time-domain pulse is fed to a spectrum analyzer or is digitally transformed, one obtains its corresponding frequency spectrum. This gives the dominant frequency ν and the badwidth Δν.

WHAT HAPPENS NOW?

Driven by the light-photon linkage “mechanism” the light spontaneously moves to lower frequencies and maintains the condition (3). I cannot see that this is forbidden in Electromagnetic Theory. This process need not violate any conservation laws – when integrated over a large volume.

So past R_ν, light from a star begins to redden, and any obsever at a distance greater than this will see this “reddening” of light. Such reddening clearly would be detectable only with reference to spectral lines of known original frequencies.

It is not correct to say that the three redshifts are equivalent.
Gravitational, cosmological, and doppler redshift are different and here's why:

I agree that the redshift seen in an accelerating reference frame is equivalent to gravitational redshift. But, in an inertial reference frame, it is just straight forward doppler redshift which is not, in any way, equivalent to gravitational redshift. And doppler redshift is also not equivalent to cosmological redshift. The universe is expanding but not, as you say, within galaxies - because the four forces (electromagnetic, strong and weak nuclear, and gravitational) hold stuff together. So the doppler redshift we see here on Earth when objects recede from us at constant speed cannot be equivalent to either gravitational or cosmological redshift. Likewise gravitational redshift is not equivalent to cosmological redshift for the same reason that it is observed here on Earth and within galaxies in which there is no expansion of space.

In fact, when observing distant binary system all three types of redshift occur and the relative contributions of doppler, cosmological, and gravitational can be separated out. So they can't possibly be equivalent.

If all you are saying is that is" looks as if" they are equivalent if examined in a certain way, then maybe. But I'm not sure that does anything but confuse anyone trying to understand that there are, in actual fact, three different types of redshift.

Doppler vs. Gravitational red-shifts can be accurately predicted based on velocity vs. gravitational time-dilation. Interpreting the cosmological redshift as a series of Doppler shifts is wrong. The cosmological redshift has nothing to do with the relative speed between emitters and observers, and we can understand the difference by doing a thought experiment. Two objects far away in space and both are at rest. The first emits a photon, and while the photon is travelling, space suddenly expands and then stops expanding before the photon reaches the second object (the observer). So, the emitter and the observer are at rest during the emission and observation, thus no Doppler effect. But still, we have the cosmological redshift.

There IS another way for photons to red shift without either doppler nor cosmological expansion --- photons themselves CAN be affected and changed by the fields they pass through, the dust gas and plasmas, magnetic fields, and gravitational fields, as they travel millions of light years between galaxies. As they pass through each gas cloud, charged field, galactic halo, etc, the photons inevitably collide with other photons just ever so slightly as to change their spin. This can result in the photon losing some of its angular momentum and having outer layers of spin stripped off, the longer it has to travel, the more fields that resist it, the more angular momentum it loses. This is especially true for very energetic photons like an X-ray, it is spinning at such a frequency that it is basically taking the most violent belligerent path possible. An X-ray is short lived because the likelihood it will collide with an atom, an electron or another photon is so high - if a photon gets absorbed and re-emitted from a proton or electron it will come out quantized at a lower frequency, categorically.   So the further the source is, the more fields a photon passes through, the more that bluer photons are stripped out, and spun down into lower frequencies which are much more predictable and simple in their path. Redder photons have the least surface area, their wavelength is basically like a long line with a slight curve rather than a billion oscillations per second, so these redder photons are able to pass through relatively unscathed. Its physics, not space.

@9:39 : well actually, yes, space (in the presence of a cosmological constant), is pulling things appart. Or more accurately, one can describe spacetime as pulling things apart with some force. Just choose another coordinate system (say a static coordinate system such as ds^2=(1-k^2*r'^2)dt'^2-dr'^2/(1-k^2*r'^2)-dOmega^2 instead of the comoving frame ds^2=dt^2-a^2(t)*(dr^2+dOmega^2). Then the cosmological constant is providing a force pulling everything away from the origin of the coordinate system (r=0) with a force proportional to distance from said origin. Such force would be akin to a cosmological Coriolis force (in mathematical origin, meaning it arises due to the choice of the coordinate system), except that it does not arise from spining but from the existence of the cosmological constant.

Yet, one would still not be expanding but expanded. Indeed, molecules, planets, stars and every compound object strong enough to old itself together despite the cosmological constant would be ever so slightly bigger than if there where no cosmological constant. But this size expansion would be finite (and quite practically unmeasurable currently), meaning things are bigger but not getting biggerrer over time.

That's the trouble with general relativity (or rather any theory obeying general covariance) because any physical interpretation of what is happening is very much dependent on how one mathematically describes the system. In the first case, the cosmological constant is quite litterally pulling things appart with a force while spacetime itself is static (i.e. not expanding) in the second, spacetime is expanding and anything embedded in it is just following it's local patch of space with no external force applied on it. Yet both description are identical as one can easily change from one description to the other (given the coordinate change is known).

What coordinate system is best to use just depends on what observable one wants to compute/compare to measurements. For instance, there is nothing wrong (neither mathematically nor physically) in saying the earth is static at the center of the universe and everything else is moving around it. But if you want to compute the trajectories of other planets in the solar system or some random star in or outside our galaxy in that coordinate system then good luck. Best to use a more appropriate coordinate system to do the computation of the trajectory and translate into earth coordinates later.

At 3:35 the rocket is at rest. At the same instant the rocket accelerates, the photon takes off as per the video. When the photon gets to the middle of the ship to have its redshift measured, the ship is going faster than it was when the light was emitted ???!!! ... How so?
In order to move ... the floor in the center of the rocket must be notified to accelerate ... by a force sent through the hull to that central floor. The implication of the video is that the "notice of acceleration" is sent instantaneously through the ship. However, that notice cannot possibly exceed the velocity of light and so arrives at the central floor ... after ... the light to be measured arrives. It arrives -after-, because the light travels a straight line whereas the "notice to accelerate" must move (at light velocity) to the sides of the ship, then up those sides, then back to the center of the middle floor which is a longer path. In the example in the video, the central floor is still "at rest" when the photon arrives to have its red shift measured so it can't possibly have changed.
This introduces the relativistic compression of an extended body by linear acceleration (which is absent from radial accelerations except as a static compression as in standing on the surface of the earth). Or, the elongation of an extended body ... if ... the engine is pulling the ship from the front instead of pushing from the rear. This simple principle is "relativistic" because it involves the speed of light ... but isn't recognized by physics as far as I know. It is also the chief causal factor in Bremsstrahlung radiation since the compression-elongation is cumulative (dependent on the total time of the acceleration) ... and the energy radiated is dependent on the stored available energy with respect to the time available for photon formation ... which is, in turn, dependent on wave-length-.

A photon observed is a photon intercepted. Each observer independently intercepts only those photons that they may intercept, by the laws of physics. The photons any observer may interact with are determined by all of the factors that influence the photon, space, and the observer system. Speaking of photons traversing past and being observed by multiple observers is such an inaccurate representation as to be invalid. Photons emitted from a common source radiate spherically outward in all directions. Those photons intercepted by any particular observer can never be intercepted by any other observer. Uniquely intercepted photons may (or may not) have sufficiently similar evolutions to provide similar measurements of their degrees of freedom for similarly situated observers and yet each observation is independently evolved into its observed state. This one-to-one relationship between the observer and the observed is the critical factor in relativity. It is why every frame and every state of space-time and its fields and DOF can seem shared and yet have unique outcomes for what seems to be a common observation. but isn't. https://www.amazon.com/dp/B07JHFDLSC

The entire video could be reduced to this:

Q: If the universe is expanding, are you also expanding?
A: No, because electro-magnetic forces overcome that expansion and keep you intact

Q: So why aren't particles individually expanding, like the single photons?
A: Particles are (for most practical purposes) point-sized entities and so they cannot expand. It's the space between them, that is expanding and sort of "pushing" them away from each other, rather than "stretching" them apart.

Q: Then why are photons red-shifting?
A: Wavelength is an emergent property dependent on the time and space around the photon - the photon itself doesn't change, the (apparent) wavelength does depending on the reference frame.

To say that someone or something expands with the universe is a meaningless tautology. The universe is our ultimate frame of reference, there is nothing beyond the fabric of space and time that we can use as a frame of reference. Therefore if something expands with the universe, It doesnt make a difference to say that it does not expand at all. This is because our frame of reference would be expanding with it.

Another important point to make is that the Universe can be defined as the set of all things that exist. It is impossible for something to exist outside the universe and expanding with the universe.

So the correct title should be, "Is the Universe expanding?" Or "Are we expanding like the rest of the Universe is?" Notice that the second option uses "the rest" to avoid including "us" two times because if we are already part of the universe, it doesnt make sense to say that we are expanding with it.

Proof by contradiction:

If the universe was expanding and we were not. Then we would not be part of the universe. By definition, everything that exists is part of the universe so we have reached the contradiction.

We can conclude not only that we are indeed expanding with the universe but also that the title of the video does no make sense from a logical standpoint.
